title: Regional Fed Leaders Disclose Their Financial Profiles
text:
Top News

Dallas Fed's Kaplan Was Active Buyer and Seller of Stocks Last Year

Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan made multiple million-dollar-plus stock trades in 2020, according to a financial disclosure form provided by his bank, in contrast with other regional Fed leaders who reported more modest financial holdings and smaller transactions.

Eleven of the 12 regional Fed banks have provided disclosures of their leaders' 2020 financial profiles since Friday, sharing information that gives insight into the holdings of officials who help set the central bank's monetary policy.

Derby's Take: NY Fed Plays Down Easy Policy Impact on Housing Prices

By Michael S. Derby

The ultra easy monetary policy pursued by the Federal Reserve over the course of the coronavirus pandemic appears to not be as big a factor in the substantial increase in home prices as many believe, according to research from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Rather, monetary policy and the related decline in interest rates has played a bigger role in driving up construction and the overall rate of home sales, bank economists Haoyang Liu, David Lucca, Dean Parker and Gabriela Rays-Wahba wrote in a report released Tuesday. Read more.

Key Developments Around the World

Fall's Economic Comeback Turns Into a September Slowdown

Earlier this summer, many economists saw the week of Labor Day as when the U.S. economic recovery would kick into high gear. Their expectation was that widespread vaccination would ease labor shortages. Schools and offices would reopen, which would mean a comeback for local businesses reliant on office workers. Travel would rebound. Stevie Nicks would be back on tour. Instead, the rise of Covid's Delta variant has the nation tapping the brakes.

Job Postings Level Off as Delta Variant Cools Demand for In-Person Workers

U.K. Among First Western Nations to Raise Taxes for Covid-19 Costs

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson Tuesday announced tax increases to support the country's state-funded National Health Service as it struggles to manage a backlog of millions of patients in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic.

China's Educational Crackdown Hits Apartment Prices in Big Cities

The market for what had been some of the most desirable apartments in China's biggest and wealthiest cities has seized up, as Beijing intensifies a campaign to open access to education.

Financial Regulation Roundup

Deals Spree Puts Banks on Track for Busiest-Ever Year

In the first eight months of 2021, companies have announced mergers and acquisitions worth more than $1.8 trillion in the U.S. and more than $3.6 trillion globally, a deal wave minting money for Wall Street. Both figures are the highest at this point in a year since at least 1995, when Dealogic started keeping records, and deals are on track to surpass their record set in 2015.

More Russian Companies Set to Join New York IPO Frenzy

Health-food provider JSC VkusVill and stock exchange PJSC SPB Exchange are preparing for initial public offerings in the U.S. this year or early next, the latest in a string of Russian corporations joining the global IPO rush.

Forward Guidance

Wednesday (all times ET)

Time N/A: National Bank of Poland releases policy statement

10 a.m.: U.S. Labor Department releases July Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey; Bank of Canada releases interest-rate announcement

1:10 p.m.: New York Fed's Williams speaks at the St. Lawrence University

2 p.m.: Federal Reserve releases beige book report on U.S. economic conditions

3 p.m.: Federal Reserve releases July U.S. consumer-credit data

6 p.m.: Dallas Fed's Kaplan speaks during a virtual town hall sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas

Thursday

7:45 a.m.: European Central Bank releases policy statement

8:30 a.m.: European Central Bank's Enria gives speech at Eurofi Forum in Ljubljana, Slovenia

11:05 a.m.: San Francisco fed's Daly speaks at the Brookings Institution Fall Conference; Chicago Fed's Evans speaks on exploring career pathways in economics and related fields

12 p.m.: Bank of Canada's Macklem gives speech

1 p.m.: Fed's Bowman speaks during the American Bankers Association Fall Government Relations Council Meeting

2 p.m.: New York Fed's Williams speaks on racism and the economy

4 p.m.: Dallas Fed's Kaplan, Minneapolis Fed's Kashkari and Boston Fed's Rosengren speaks on racism and the economy

4:25 p.m.: Boston Fed's Rosengren speaks on racism and the economy

Research

Global Food Price Jump May Herald Persistent Inflation Gains

Surging food prices around the world could be a sign that rising inflation may be breaking out from factors tied directly to coronavirus pandemic disruptions, a J.P. Morgan report said Tuesday. "Although the rise in global CPI inflation earlier this year was concentrated in energy and a narrow set of goods prices linked to supply constraints, the acceleration in food prices, alongside a recent pickup in services price inflation, sends a signal that pandemic-related pressures on prices are broadening," the report said. It added that, "While we believe much of this pressure will prove transitory, inflation should remain elevated through early next year, as rising food and services price inflation offsets a moderation in energy and core goods price gains."

—Michael S. Derby

Commentary

What if China's Property Crackdown Goes Overboard Too?

China's regulatory crackdown has wiped billions off technology companies' market value, but the continuing squeeze on real estate—if allowed to run much further—could have even bigger repercussions, Jacky Wong writes.

Basis Points

Intel Corp. plans to build new chip-making facilities in Europe valued at up to $95 billion, responding to a cross-border race to add manufacturing capacity at a time of a global chip-supply crunch.

The market for high-end apartments in China's biggest and wealthiest cities has seized up, as Beijing intensifies a campaign to open access to education.

Economic expectations in Germany have declined for the fourth consecutive month, the ZEW economic research institute said, noting its measure of economic expectations decreased from 40.4 in August to 26.5 in September. (Dow Jones Newswires)

German industrial production increased in July, beating forecasts despite widespread supply shortages, Destatis said, noting that total industrial output rose 1.0% from June in calendar-adjusted terms. Economists had forecast a 0.7% increase, according to a poll by The Wall Street Journal. (DJN)

The eurozone economy grew more than initially estimated in the second quarter. Eurostat said gross domestic product across the bloc expanded by 2.2% from the first quarter, compared with a previous estimate of 2% growth. The economy grew 14.3% on year, compared with the 13.7% forecast of economists polled by WSJ. (DJN)

The Conference Board Employment Trends Index, which measures U.S. employment trends, increased from 109.89 in July to 110.37 in August, its sixth consecutive monthly increase, according to data published Tuesday. (DJN)

Fiscal policy in Canada last year to mitigate the pandemic's effect on incomes had a profound impact on the country's lower and middle classes, Statistics Canada said. The gap between the highest and lowest income earners narrowed to the lowest level on record. (DJN)

Mexico's auto industry sees the global shortage of semiconductors continuing at least through the end of this year, and has abandoned its expectation of 12% growth in output and exports of cars and light trucks in 2021. Production is now expected to be similar to 2020 levels, according to industry association AMIA. (DJN)
